job_title: Admin Assistant in Chula Vista, CA

job_title: Therapist in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent benefits and can maintain work life balance depending on the department
cons: The substance use department as a whole is managed by the most unprofessional group of people. With leadership there is significant lack of transparency, differential treatment, significant lack of knowledge of ethics/laws related to treatment, and overall unprofessionalism. Turn over is very high, remaining staff are overworked and there have been racism accusations throughout my time there that are simply glossed over. If you want to grow and get mentorship this is not the place for you. Also if you’re a person of color, avoid. Many leaders in the department are in recovery themselves and make the entire treatment about their experience. HR is useless and retaliation is rampant.

job_title: Associate Director in San Diego, CA
pros: I came to Family Health Centers hoping to learn more about integrated mental health and primary care. I definitely got that and so much more. It is thrilling to work in a place that values whole person care particularly for underserved communities. While I knew that I would learn more about integrated care, what I didn’t anticipate was all the new opportunities for me to be inspired by our department leaders, executive management, and also my fellow colleagues. I have grown so much in terms of my clinical, managerial, and organizational skills. The other thing I didn’t expect was the new and innovative ways that I have been involved in diversity equity and inclusion efforts, either through membership on a DEI council or workgroup, or through culturally-based trainings and related community engagement activities. I especially enjoy the monthly diversity trainings that are available for the mental health staff. My schedule is jam-packed, but there are many times during a week when I will take time to reflect on how I’m happy to be here at FHCSD. I am so glad that I took the plunge to switch gears in my professional path to come work at FHCSD. The work is challenging, but also very rewarding because of the clients, the colleagues, and support from leadership.
cons: Given that the organization keeps growing, sometimes it takes time for new initiatives to be implemented.

job_title: Medical Assistant in San Diego, CA

job_title: Physician, Family Practice in San Diego, CA
pros:
1) A large and well established organization serving the underserved in San Diego since the 1980's. Majority of staff are mission driven and care about serving the underserved.
2) Variety of clinic sites to work from which have their own subculture and style
3) Full time is 32 hours per week of clinic time plus 4 hours of admin time (36 hrs/week) to receive benefits
4) Opportunities for remote practice/telehealth and work in different subspecialties (HIV, Hepatitis Clinic, Mobile Clinic, Refugee Health, Weight Management), etc.
5) Has a Family Medicine Residency and soon will be starting a Psychiatry residency. Options for teaching available.
6) Salaries are getting better from before. Benefits are fairly competitive for an FQHC
7) Employment here qualifies for most loan forgiveness programs
8) Leadership team (CEO, CMO, etc) have been with organization for a long time and are very dedicated to the mission/organization. Still feels like a grassroots and progressive organization.
cons:
1) They are trying to improve salaries to match market in San Diego but pay could be more competitive
2) Provider meetings are generally after hours or during lunch.
3) Given its a large company, there is a disconnect at times between staff in the clinic sites and medical leadership.
4) Patient population is very complicated (various languages spokes, high pathology, multiple medical conditions, complex psycho-social-financial logistical issues) and there is only 20 min per appointment. Even for physicals, establish care, and hospital follow-up visits.
5) Work life balance is poor as there is too much work to finish in a standard work week. Many providers are charting from home or managing their inbox over the weekend.

job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros:
This is a wonderful organization.  The mission is to make sure everyone has access to health care, and every decision and action centers around achieving this goal.  It's not a place for slackers- employees are expected to be high performers that care about their patients and work.  Good performance is rewarded with annual pay increases, great benefits (for employee and family members), and generous time off (all employees start with 15 PTO days a year + paid holidays.)

The CEO expects a lot from her team, but that is not a surprise from someone who helped grow the organization from one small clinic in Barrio Logan to one of the largest health centers in the nation.  She doesn't just give orders, she helps get the work done and she is a great mentor for anyone that wants to work hard and get ahead.  

The best part about working at Family Health Centers of San Diego is the impact you make in the patients' lives.  You help people at pivotal, scary moments in their lives, like when they are just diagnosed with breast cancer or HIV or their child is sick.  You're part of a team that ensures they get access to the care they need (regardless of whether they have insurance), and helps them get back on their feet.  You always leave at the end of the day knowing that you made a difference.
cons: Working with disadvantaged patient populations isn't always easy.  You have to be willing to go the extra mile for patients that are facing many personal challenges and aren't always immediately appreciative.  But, in the long run, the pros vastly outweigh the cons.

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work environment to work for
cons: None on this company yet

job_title: Supervisor/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: In my career at FHCSD there has been consistent opportunity for professional growth and development. I feel that upper management has been very approachable and engaged with all levels of staff. I'm encouraged to keep up my professional practice through covered trainings, onsite coaching and consultation. I've been given the opportunity to hire and develop a diverse group of staff members that are committed to serving the mission of the organization. In practical terms, some of the general "pros" are: coworkers are nice and easy to interact with, people make an effort to say "good morning" to each other, there is a culture of health and wellbeing that is genuinely supported, benefits provide very good coverage including 401k matching.
cons: The downside to working at FHC is that we work several days that other companies cover as paid holidays. However I firmly believe that we work theses days because it is important to keep our community clinics open and running to serve people who may be ill and in need of care. I liken this to the hospital model of care....Hospitals don't close; ever. Our community clinics serve a vital purpose and therefore must run at a pace that serves the community.

review_title: Horrible place to work as a provider
job_title: Physician Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: You get the chance to care for the underserved, which is what drew me to apply to work there.
cons: There are some key things that make this place a nightmare to work for, speaking only from the role of a healthcare practioner. Clinic bosses are not medically trained. There are certain people that get certain privelages but you don't know who those people are until you see someone offend one or you offend one.  Somehow, mysteriously, you get transferred within a day or 2 of stepping on their toes, then you usually "offend" someone else or "word gets out" that you offended so-and-so and you're Treated horribly until you're fired or quit.  It happens constantly. That is one of the primary reasons for practioner turnover. It's not discussed. Some docs become favorites and will never get fired . Others fall into the pit--no one "taught them how to blend in". And no one ever told them nurses have way more power than healthcare providers. If you want to help the homeless and underserved, find another way. This job has the potential to hurt you in the long run.  Management (which is very, very big) is very, very vindictive. They may try to ruin your career. They tried like hell to ruin the career of a friend of mine.

job_title: Referral Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits and vacation time
cons: Workload ratio per employee = overworked

review_title: FHCSD does a lot of good for the community, but it works its employees to the bone.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: The clinic is a regional leader in providing affordable care to poor people. The clinic is staffed by people who are very committed to serving others.
cons: There is no work-life balance at Family Health Centers. People with hourly jobs (like physicians) are able to do their job and leave. However, everyone else works late all the time. If the administration would hire a few secretaries that might not be the case. But mostly, you're looking to get an answer to every question you have from some high-level employee who has no administrative assistant, and those people are all drowning in paper, voicemail, and misery.

review_title: Only Unionization Could Save This Messed Up, Hostile Workplace
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I have been here for over 10 years and stayed because the clinic helps hundreds of thousands of people every year. It is work that matters
cons: Upper and middle management is not stable because of the behavior of one individual. I have never seen so many directors and high managers leave as in the past couple years. Micromanagement everywhere. Silos. No information sharing. Understaffing. People are fed up. The sense of "family" no longer exists like in the old days. All of the vacation days we used to get have been taken away, and are now down to 7. Sick time has gone away and now it is PTO. So, if you are sick, it comes out of your vacation time...which you really need if you work here. The only people with continuing education benefits are M.D.s, but they can afford it. There is no assistance to help others move up. So instead they move out. The Board that is supposed to run the health center never asks employees what they think, and no one knows who they are. They have no idea how unhappy the workers are.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: FHCSD provides important healthcare services to members of the community who might otherwise not receive any, and the overall mission is meaningful. Employees are dedicated and work hard to serve the patients.
cons: Many employees are dissatisfied and struggling to manage an extremely high caseload in the mental health department. Employees feel voiceless and have very little control over their working conditions. Attempts to improve work conditions are futile—there will continue to be very high employee turnover until management starts to listen and treat employee input as meaningful.

review_title: I loved helping people, red tape of the company not so much
job_title: Homeless Services Navigator in San Diego, CA
pros: get access to tools to help people. team members are still some of my friends
cons: management is too over your shoulder. I did not feel supported in my role. I would never talk about this to other people because I loved my role and my job to help others but the work was very stressful and my supervisors were not responsive to my needs. I have clearly communicated my frustrations with my clients and how I needed support, but my manager did not know what to do (or connect me to people who did). I felt that even though management was paid MUCH more than me, I cared more about the population we were assigned to serve.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Family Health Centers of San Diego has a great mission--providing quality healthcare to everyone, particularly those from underserved communities.  I appreciate the opportunity to be part of this mission and, at the same time, earn a good living with good benefits to support my family.  The people I work with are dedicated, hard-working, and team-oriented; many of whom have been with the organization many years.  The organization is growing fast, which means there are plenty of opportunities for advancement and career development, and the support to do so with a tuition reimbursement program and mentoring.  I highly recommend the organization to anyone wanting to work with an organization with a compelling mission and the opportunity to make thousands and thousands of lives better.
cons: Healthcare is rapidly changing and the organization is growing very fast, which sometimes puts pressure on employees.  However, it's great to be part of a strong organization that is growing fast--lots of opportunities and it's very interesting to be a part of it all.

review_title: Dissatisfied with the blatant favoritism that happens so often.
job_title: Patient Engagement Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: I like the mission of the company and what FHCSD has done for the community . I like how this company does help so many people who need health services who may otherwise not have access to care.
cons: This company is a complete joke and cannot be taken seriously. This company is plagued  by favoritism! There are individuals who have no college degree making  higher wages than that of a college graduate.  They bend and edit job descriptions to get certain people in jobs that would usually require a degree. Sad to say but this company caters to their Mexican employees and they run the show. If you are African American good luck being treated fairly in the workplace. They bring in their cousin's, sister, brother, girlfriend, etc who have no experience but they get the jobs and the better pay. It's all in who you know to get your foot in the door. I wish the CEO would take a close look at FHCSD's turnover rate and the company's overall hiring process. This company is not a good place to work for.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
FHCSD is a mission driven organization - the mission is to serve everyone in need, and that is accomplished every day.  The health center offers comprehensive medical and support services for all age levels.  There is a culture of continuous improvement that is disseminated to all employees.  
There are many opportunities for advancement to those individuals who demonstrate committment and perseverance.
cons: If there is a con, it is that only individuals whose mission or calling in life is to serve the underserved succeed at an organization such as FHCSD.  This is really not a con - it is a privilege to those who belief in a service oriented organization that strives to serve the health care needs of everyone in need.

job_title: Physician Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Family Health Centers is a dynamic & multicultural workplace.  We are a large group of clinics distributed around San Diego county (>35 at last count), each its unique attributes.  I find my workplace a positive and cooperative environment.  My patients vary in age from 19 to 98 years of age.  They come from a variety of ethnic, economic and cultural backgrounds.  My next patient may be a middle-class working adult, a parent, a young person going through a drug rehab program, someone dealing with depression, someone with a work injury, diabetes, hypertension.  If you're interested in enjoying your work and having a positive impact on our community, this is a great place to be.
cons: Because of our diverse locations & schedules, we have once-quarterly meetings in the evening.  So free diner but no free time that night.  The meetings are at least a chance to meet up with your colleagues.

job_title: Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: The best part about working for FHCSD is the patients.  We have wonderful patients that are a pleasure to serve.  The mission of the organization is to provide excellent medical and dental care to the underserved and we hold true to this mission.  No one works here that does not care about helping others.
cons: The morale among the doctors is low.  We are underpaid and work very hard.  It is very hard to raise a family when working the number of hours they expect us to work.  Many excellent doctors leave after working here for a few years.  They just can't continue to survive working 60-70 hours a week.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: I think this is a good place to get your foot in the door and begin your career in the medical field. There are a lot of opportunities to grow as long as you persevere and you find the right people to talk to. I think that even though they may not pay as well as other places, you can gain a lot of knowledge and move forward to a different company if you wish, or you can even grow within the company. Even though there are a few things that bothered me about this company, I still felt satisfied that I was given the opportunity to learn new skills ( I had no admin experience before this job) and I was able to expand my resume and now I am able to apply to different jobs with better pay :-)
cons: lower pay relative to similar clinics

job_title: Clinical Psychologist in Redlands, CA
pros:
Here are a few reasons I loved working for Family Health Centers of San Diego.

1. The company is very stable and I never felt my job was at stake.
2. The FHCSD has a group of leaders who are committed to patient care and that seems to be their priority
3. I felt supported and my supervisors were available to consult and provide the leadership I needed.
4. The building are kept clean and there is a sense of pride working for them.
5. The most important for me was the Integrated Care provided by FHCSD including Primary Care, Psychiatry, Psychology, Women's Health and many other aspects of healthcare working together to help the whole person.
cons: The demand for mental health care is great but the challenges of finding enough providers seem to be a problem for all agencies in San Diego.

job_title: Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Worked here for over a decade full-time. I would never consider leaving here. My coworkers rare like family and the benefits are excellent. Every day I come to work I honestly feel I am helping people, especially because they struggle to get by, and the health center means so much to them. It feels good to know I play a part in helping people overcome their health issues.Our CEO is always expanding our services so we can reach more people, and the ability to achieve grants helps us work with hard-to-reach and often ignored populations.
cons: Former workers should quit trying to hurt the health center with their toxic rants. They need to just move on. Wish there were more night clinics for people work days.

job_title: MFTI Mental Health Therapist in Spring Valley, CA
pros: Colleagues; Family Hours; Supervision provided; good benefits; some training paid for; make your own schedule to see children in school setting.
cons: Management; summer schedule hours are significantly reduced; county paperwork is overwhelming, never-ending, and constantly increasing or changing; staff works on their own time in order to complete piled up paperwork.

review_title: Management does not know how to treat employees. They only use people to their convenience.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Some supervisors are flexible when in need of taking time off.
cons: People are not treated with respect and employees are underpaid. Managers do not want to help their staff succeed. The mission of this organization is to help people in need, yet employees and patients are treated poorly. When a patient complains about the type of service they are receiving the supervisors don't do anything. This organization does not care about their patients. All they want is to make money. Supervisors do not want to be responsible about anything and all they do is use their employees.

job_title: Engagement Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Family Health Centers Of San Diego is a great place to work. You have the opportunity to grow and great benefits, FHCSD provides great support and services to the Community
cons: We san improve by having more Clinics specific to dental care, more prevention programs and programs that support people with Chronic diseases also I think we can have a Specialist Clinic for Seniors Care because the needs of this population is growing.

review_title: A mission driven organization with a healthy respect for the bottom line.
job_title: Support Services in San Diego, CA
pros: Family Health Centers truly cares about the mission and the people they serve. They look out for the needs of the patients and find ways to meet that need. But, they also understand that they have to maintain a sound financial footing if they want to stay in business, or better yet, expand their services to care for more people.
cons: It is a passionate team that works very hard to meet their mission. This is not a job for a slacker or someone looking for a easy 9-5 place. But, if you are willing to work hard, you can go home at night knowing that you have helped a lot of families.

job_title: Associate in San Diego, CA
pros:
Commute is okay, neighborhoods are a bit shady
The HR team are great, though they are all new so I doubt they will stay long
People are great up to a certain employee level
There are other opportunities out there so consider those first
cons:
CEO has rigid ideas and are a very old fashioned way of thinking 
You will hate every minute you work here as no one will listen to you or train you properly
They terminate a lot of people so don't get too attached
Although I didn't get termed, I don't see why they fire everyone
Management is a mess and have no idea what they are doing
The IT department takes ages to do anything. Either they are over worked or under skilled
You however will work a lot of hours and get nothing to show for it

review_title: Never a boring moment but it does get old.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay, set scheduled hours. Bi-weekly payday. Great benefits (Low bi-weekly for Kaiser). Medical, dental, life, 401k, retirement, etc. Co-workers can become like family and are the only reason you go back to work every day. It feels rewarding helping out the community.
cons: Some employees can be rude and disrespectful perhaps due to the stressful environment. Some patients can be very impatient lash out you. Sitting at a computer 40 hrs/wk can be very deteriorating to your physical health.

review_title: Great Mission, but providers are not appreciated or compensated well
job_title: Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: Service mission. Flexibility to care for very underserved population who are not being served by other health systems.
cons: Administrators wield the power and are very stingy, demanding more productivity and offering less reimbursement.  Providers are simply not supported.  Very high turnover

job_title: Call Center Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: I love working for this organization.  Ever since I first read the mission of FHCSD, I felt impelled to work here.  It is an organization that provides excellent healthcare services to their patients  and cares for their employees as well.   This workplace allows me to balance my work and family life. FHCSD provides and promotes career growth to anyone that is interested in pursuing a career.  Working here has been a blessing.
cons: No cons.  This is a place to work for, if you are a hardworking person and if you really want to make a difference in the community.

review_title: High stress, nice staff, mgmt doesn't value providers
job_title: Physician Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
-See very interesting pathology, higher acuity practice than you'd find anywhere else.
-Staff & providers are supportive, friendly, and have good integrity.
cons:
-Management's only priority is how many patients you see in a day, they don't value employees so there's a high turnover rate at Logan. 
-Extremely low pay for providers.
-Most sick leave is taken away from vacation time.
-Stressful, complex population but still only 15 minutes to see each patient.

review_title: I gained marketable skills and my boss treated everyone with respect.
job_title: Health Educator in San Diego, CA
pros: Opportunity to be creative, cared for some of San Diego's sickest patients, received constructive feedback from supervisors, team spirit, training and educational opportunities, developed community connections, enabled me to expand my comfort zones, variety of ever-changing job duties. The department I worked in (HIV Services) received certain job perks and a more relaxed work culture than other departments in the agency.
cons: The playing of politics is required, ineffective coworkers with messy personal lives were tolerated, "competitive pay" = median but with reliable increases during performance reviews.

review_title: Very top heavy  non medically trained management
job_title: Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: If you enjoy working with the under served this job gives you the opportunity.
cons: Constant gossiping, low pay, thankless (from the staff) job.  No warnings if you do something improperly--they just fire you.  They have a hard time keeping physicians.  Many only last 3-4 months which makes for a disorganized system. One clinic I worked at hadn't had an MD for over 2years. Far more mid-levels than doctors.

job_title: Associate Clinic Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great experience to learn skills pertinent for health management. Company is very mission driven and provides care at many angles to help it's patients. Company is always growing so there is lots of room for growth within the organization.
cons: Can be long hours as there is lots of work to be done. The pay is adequate but not outstanding.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Mission driven organization that does amazing work for the various communities in San Diego. If you're looking for a company where you feel that you are making a difference in the world, this is it. Whether you are in patient care or on the organizational side of things, the work you are doing truly impacts people's lives.
cons:
Very busy environment, by no means will you have a lack of work to do.

Pay is on the lower end, but that is to be expected with a nonprofit like this. If you choose to work here it's for the mission, not the salary.

job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Amazing nonprofit organization.  I love its mission of providing quality healthcare services to everyone, especially to the underserved members of the patient population who need it the most.  It is rapidly expanding its access points to reach many more families throughout San Diego County, which is an exciting time at the moment!  Looking through my healthcare admin “lenses,” I am confident this company will continue to remain as a valuable resource to the community in decades to come.  If you are creative, flexible to changing process, energetic, resourceful, and above all, have the heart to serve others, this is the place for you to not only grow in your career, but to love what you do.  I have worked in a number of large healthcare organizations before, ranging from Kaiser Permanente to Blue Cross Blue Shield, and this has been by far the most rewarding experience for me, considering the direct impact work has on the most vulnerable members of society.  Throughout the past 5 plus years I have been here, I had the opportunity to work in clinic operations and now the main offices, which is an experience that has evolved into a dream job.  I go home at the end of most days feeling like I made a difference.  Coming from a military family who often has an unstable schedule and competing personal priorities at the home front, the Management has only been supportive of both my personal and professional development.  I have seen colleagues and Providers come and go, and some of them end up coming right back.  The work is hard, it can be thankless and unappreciated at times, particularly by patients who can be overbearing and are often quick to complain.  Our structure and situations change frequently.  But if you take a moment to realize that the healthcare system is complex and life for our patient population is beyond difficult, you will understand your purpose of serving others.   I often advise incoming employees and volunteers to make the most of every opportunity.  You reap what you sow.  Plant good seeds!
cons: I have a few colleagues who are primarily task-oriented and lack the strategic “big picture” view necessary to maintain employee engagement.  Communication has been a challenge across departments, but leadership is aware of this from survey feedback, and is making efforts to manage the delivery of information effectively.  The rapid growth has been both an amazing accomplishment as well as a concern, since the speed at which the company is expanding often inadvertently prevents involvement by key employees and supervisors.  Part of natural growing pains of any organization.

job_title: Reception in San Diego, CA
pros: Working for this company is a stepping stone to add to you're resume and will open the doors to get hired at exp: Sharp, kaiser, scripps and or other bigger companies.
cons: Employees are over worked and under paid. Raises are once a year in October with a raise of no more than 40 cent at that if you're lucky. Employees do not receive much recognition. The company just cares about meeting a certain amount of numbers each month, meaning the amount of pt's seen.

review_title: Too much supervising, feels like we are felons
job_title: Medical Assistant in Spring Valley, CA
pros: Great benefits,  growing  company with lots of room for someone new in the healthcare industry
cons: Too much money and time spent policing employees that they deemed capable at the hiring time to then decide  they  need constant supervision and harassment.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Great Organization, great benefits, great cause. Worked in some teams that had a family like atmosphere. Most employees are not here for the pay, but because it's a great organization and they are out to help people.
cons: it's funded by Federal/State/Country funds, so budget cuts causes layoffs regularly. Had several friends get let go during the tough economy and california budget cuts.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The majority of the people who work here are hard-working team players and it's easy to make lifelong friends here. I did not use the health benefits, but heard that they were comparable to those offered by Sharp or Kaiser. Time-off accrual is at a decent rate. Company values motivate employees to continue growing within the company.
cons: Compensation is generally much lower than other employers within San Diego county, but this is expected since it is a non-profit organization. Some members of management can be very difficult to work with.

review_title: No leadership. No room for advancement. Not a good place to work if you have any other choices.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Some regular day to day staff are really neat people. You get to make a difference in patient populations that truly need the help.
cons: No communication between departments. Poor morale across the board amongst the workforce. Directors are given a "do whatever you want and get away with it" badge. Upper management could care less about the common employees concerns. Poor benefits. A non-functioning HR/Accounting dept. And top it all off with long hours for terrible pay.

review_title: Loved the work, room to expand role
job_title: Community Health Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: This organization serves people who aren't receiving care elsewhere. This organization is extremely fast growing and has expanded their services to reach out of the traditional community clinic sphere. They are community leaders in addressing homeless services.
cons: This organization's biggest downfall is the low wages. They were not sustainable for living in the city of San Diego.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: "I need a job to earn an honest living, and this company is a place where my qualifications can make a difference.
cons: Quality of life will vary greatly depending on the team you get assigned to. Being part of a good team will make life wonderful, a bad team will make  life miserable. Whom we work with has a major influence on  our career (don't expect promotions in a dying product). Internal transfers are hard.

review_title: Strong Work Environment with a Commitment to Continuous Improvment.
job_title: Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros: Family Health Centers has a mission oriented to helping under priveledged and uninsured individuals.  This mission drives the organization.  Company is dedicated to continuous improvement and works to develop strong protocols to meet the mission.  Management and many employees are dedicated professionals.  Providers / Phyiscians offer quality care to patients.  CEO and leadership care about making a difference in people's lives.
cons: Patient wait times and number of providers are challenges.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Job security
- Benefits
- Good cause
- competitive pay spending on position

cons:

job_title: Vision CLinic Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Working with this organization for 13 years I still feel  it as my Family, this is my second home, very nice and comfortable work  environment, very stable job and great opportunity to growth and to help uninsured and medically undeserved persons
cons: Too many policies and rules that some times results obsoletes and unproductive. In order to make changes that allows us to improve some times takes too long.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Manager helps you balance your personal life with work. You get to meet some nice people
cons: be ready to work long hours, if allowed to do over time. They are very special when it comes to over time. You will have a lot of work and little help. Over worked, no support, blamed for everything, looked down upon if your not a provider. No appreciate for hard work. Underpaid.

review_title: Management dysfunctional.  Focus is on gaining market share, not providing best care to patients.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Organization serves a population that really needs its services.  Self-starters are able to take on as much responsibility as they want.
cons: Management dysfunction is severe.  Managers do not have basic management skills, and are not provided training.   Staff are always working in emergency mode because of poor long-term and short term planning.   Organization does not reflect back on past steps, so mistakes and problems continue on and on.

job_title: Medical Assistant (MA) III in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits, always busy, nice co-workers. You get to meet a lot of people and you are learning new things every day.
cons: When you have a very rude patient sometimes your clinic director might not be by your side, it's all about numbers at this place. It seems that's what each clinic is trying to reach, having the higher number of patients, instead of giving the highest of quality care to the patient.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: A rewarding company since you're helping others. vacation time was good and nice people to work with.
cons: Overwhelmed with job responsibilities,  too much work, work many overtime hours, poor management with no communication skills

review_title: Do not let yourself work here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

cons: Employees are treated very poorly.  Senior management tries to motivate employees through fear, not by coaching or encouraging them.

review_title: Top down management- pretend to respect you but only to get more out of you.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
